snippet: Carolina dogs, like a few other breeds, are without certain genetic markers indicating European origins, suggesting they have been in the Americas since the last Ice Age.
abstract: Peter Savolainen study of canine DNA in journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B provides evidence that Carolina dogs, breed commonly found in South Carolina, are without genetic markers indicative of European origin, suggesting they arrived in earlier migration from Asia; study and its results, long suspected by locals, reawakens debate about how and where dogs were domesticated.
lead_paragraph: Carolina dogs, like a few other breeds, are without certain genetic markers indicating European origins, suggesting they have been in the Americas since the last Ice Age.

headline.main: DNA Backs Lore on Pre-Columbian Dogs
headline.print_headline: A Dog That Goes Way Back

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)
